Using HEAD, I was able to get an illegal argument exception updating a label in the debug view. I had launched and quickly terminated a target. It looks like it's possible to set a label to "null" in this case.

Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Argument cannot be null
    at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3518)
    at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3457)
    at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3428)
    at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.error(Widget.java:432)
    at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TreeItem.setText(TreeItem.java:1752)
    at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.viewers.model.LabelUpdate.update(LabelUpdate.java:164)
    at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.viewers.model.TreeModelLabelProvider$1.runInUIThread(TreeModelLabelProvider.java:255)
    at org.eclipse.ui.progress.UIJob$1.run(UIJob.java:94)
    at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35)
    at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:123)

Fixed in HEAD

If the label text is null, it is changed to an empty string.

See LabelUpdate.

To reproduce, have a breakpoint set at which a lot of variables are displayed in the variables view.  Launch the program and use the keyboard shortcut to terminate it.  If you get the timing correctly, the program will terminate part way through displaying the variables, producing the error.
